Refers to the time of day an animal is t: A grouping that includes gorillas, chimpanzees, bonobos, humans, and their extinct relatives.

When two or more taxa exhibit similar traits that have evolved independently, the similar traits evolve due to similar selective pressures. (Also sometimes called convergent evolution, parallel evolution, or homoplasy.)
A trait that has been inherited from a distant ancestor.
A descriptor for an organism that spends most of its time in trees.
A grouping that includes orangutans and their extinct relatives.
Molar pattern of cercopithecoid monkeys in which there are usually four cusps that are arranged in a square pattern and connected by two ridges.
Walking on two legs.
A form of locomotion in which the organism swings below branches using the forelimbs.
Low, rounded cusps on the cheek teeth.
In most primates, these are the longest of the teeth, often conical in shape and used as a weapon against predators or others of their species.
Active throughout the 24-hour period.
A grouping based on ancestral relationships; a branch of the evolutionary tree.
The bumps on the chewing surface of the premolars and molars, which can be quite sharp in some species.
The number of each type of tooth in one quadrant of the mouth, written as number of incisors: canines: premolars: molars.
A trait that has been recently modified, most helpful when assigning taxonomic classification.
A space between the teeth, usually for large canines to fit when the mouth is closed.
Being able to see only blues and greens.
Active during the day.
The nose and upper lip are separated and the upper lip can move independently; sometimes referred to as a “hairy” or “mobile” upper lip.
A subarea of anthropology that studies the complexities of human-primate relationships in the modern environment.
When an organism, which is limited in the time and energy it can put into aspects of its biology and behavior, is shaped by natural selection to invest in one adaptation at the expense of another.
Having a diet consisting entirely of animal matter
Having a diet consisting primarily of leaves.
A depressed area in the retina at the back of the eye containing a concentration of cells that allow one to focus on objects very close to one’s face.
Having a diet consisting primarily of fruit.
A trait that is useful for a wide range of tasks.
A grouping based on overall similarity in lifestyle, appearance, and behavior.
A claw present on the second pedal digit in strepsirrhines.
Having a diet consisting primarily of gums and saps.
Having different types of teeth.
When two or more taxa share characteristics because they inherited them from a common ancestor.
When primates sharpen their canines by wearing them on adjacent teeth.
The spatula-shaped teeth at the front of the mouth.
Having a diet consisting primarily of insects.
Modified seat bones of the pelvis that are flattened and over which calluses form; function as seat pads for sitting and resting atop branches.
A form of quadrupedal movement used by Gorilla and Pan when on the ground, wherein the front limbs are supported on the knuckles of the hands.
Refers to an organism’s pace of growth, reproduction, lifespan, etc.
How an organism moves around.
Refers to the alternative reproductive strategies in orangutans in which males can delay maturation, sometimes indefinitely, until a fully mature, “flanged” male disappears.
The largest teeth at the back of the mouth; used for chewing. In primates, these teeth usually have between three and five cusps.
Being able to see only in shades of light to dark, no color.
When males and females of a species do not exhibit significant sexual dimorphism.
Refers to the contrasting fur color of baby leaf monkeys compared to adults.
Active at night.
Bony projection at the elbow end of the ulna.
Having thumbs and toes that go in a different direction from the rest of the fingers, allows for grasping with hands and feet.
Activity pattern: Opposable thumb or opposable big toe

Refers to the time of day an animal is t: Having five digits or fingers and toes.
A system in which individuals of a species vary in their abilities to see color. In primates, it refers to males being dichromatic and females being either trichromatic or dichromatic.
A bony ring that surrounds the eye socket, open at the back.
A bony plate that provides protection to the side and back of the eye.
A tail that is able to hold the full body weight of an organism, which often has a tactile pad on the underside of the tip for improved grip.
Smaller than the molars, used for chewing. In primates, these teeth usually have one or two cusps.
Moving around on all fours.
Wet noses; resulting from naked skin of the nose which connects to the upper lip and smell-sensitive structures along the roof of the mouth.
A bony ridge along the top/middle of the skull, used for attachment of chewing muscles.
The behavior of rubbing scent glands or urine onto objects as a way of communicating with others.
A form of locomotion in which an organism swings below branches using a combination of forelimbs and prehensile tail.
When a species exhibits sex differences in morphology, behavior, hormones, and/or coloration.
Sharpened ridges that connect cusps on a bilophodont molar.
A trait that has been modified for a specific purpose.
A bony projection of the ulna at the end near the wrist.
Sensitive skin at the fingertips for sense of touch. Animals with a prehensile tail have a tactile pad on the underside of the tail as well.
Reflecting layer at the back of the eye that magnifies light.
A descriptor for an organism that spends most of its time on the ground.
Having the ability to see reds, yellows, blues, greens, and ultraviolet.
A trait of the front, lower teeth of strepsirrhines in which, typically, the four incisors and canines are long and thin and protrude outward.
Being able to distinguish yellows and reds in addition to blues and greens.
A locomotor pattern in which animals are oriented upright while clinging to vertical branches, push off with hind legs, and land oriented upright on another vertical branch.
Molar cusp pattern in which five molar cusps are separated by a “Y”-shaped groove pattern.
